summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana judgment arose from a labor dispute where the National Labour Commission (NLC) sought enforcement of its order against Crocodile Matchets Ghana Ltd. for unfair termination of five employees. The NLC had appointed a two-member committee to hear the case, which issued an order later enforced by the High Court. The Court of Appeal set aside the decision, citing lack of quorum and improper delegation. The Supreme Court upheld this reversal, holding that Section 140(3) of the Labour Act, 2003 (Act 651) requires a quorum of five members, including tripartite representation, to settle industrial disputes. The Court found no statutory basis for a two-member panel to exercise judicial functions and emphasized that mandatory quorum provisions must be strictly observed. The appeal was dismissed, affirming that non-compliance invalidates proceedings.
verdict: The appeal by the National Labour Commission was dismissed. The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's decision that the two-member committee lacked quorum and could not validly exercise the Commission's judicial functions under the Labour Act, 2003.
citations: Boateng v Volta Aluminium Co. Ltd [1984-86] 1GLR 733
Boyefio v NTHC Properties Ltd. [1996-97] SCGLR 531
rationaleHighlights: Statutes must be read as a whole and interpreted in pari materia, especially where provisions relate to the same subject.
Section 140(3) mandates a quorum of five for the Commission to settle industrial disputes, including representation from government, labor, and employers.
No statutory provision authorizes a two-member committee to exercise the Commission’s judicial functions, rendering such proceedings invalid.
The Court of Appeal correctly held that the two-member panel lacked quorum and that delegation was not properly established on record.
The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision due to lack of compliance with mandatory quorum requirements.
